text: Galia Angelova (born 10 November 1972) is a Bulgarian former professional tennis player. ==Biography== Angelova, who comes from Haskovo, was a member of the Bulgaria Federation Cup team which competed in the 1988 and 1990 competitions, featuring in a total of eight ties. Her only WTA Tour main draw appearance came in the doubles at the 1989 Vitosha New Otani Open in Sofia. She won three ITF singles titles and had a best ranking of 378 in the world. As a doubles player she was ranked as high as 231 and won five ITF doubles titles. She is now a tennis coach and works at Dema Sport in Sofia. ==ITF finals== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:85%;" width=15% |- style="background:lightblue;" | $25,000 tournaments |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" | $10,000 tournaments |} ===Singles (3-1)=== {| class="sortable wikitable" style="font-size:97%;" |- !Outcome !No. !Date !Tournament !Surface !Opponent !Score |- bgcolor="#f0f8ff" | style="background:#98fb98;"|Winner | 1. | 2 September 1990 | Palermo, Italy | Clay | Carmela Vitali | 6–4, 6–3 |- bgcolor="#f0f8ff" | style="background:#98fb98;"|Winner | 2. | 17 June 1991 | Covilhã, Portugal | Clay | Sofia Prazeres | 3–6, 6–4, 6–1 |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" | style="background:#98fb98;"|Winner | 3. | 8 March 1992 | Ramat HaSharon, Israel | Hard | Gina Niland | 6–4, 7–5 |- bgcolor="#f0f8ff" | bgcolor="FFA07A"|Runner-up | 1. | 25 September 1994 | Varna, Bulgaria | Clay | Dora Djilianova | 4–6, 3–6 |} ===Doubles (5–4)=== {|class="sortable wikitable" style=font-size:97% |- !
